Award.AwardTitle: Conference Participation Support Proposal - 20th Annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates; Pittsburgh, PA; Oct 25 - 28, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide funds to partially support the 20th annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU), which is held as part of the Fall Meeting of the APS Division of Nuclear Physics. This year's meeting will be held October 25 - 28, 2017, in Pittsburgh, PA. The CEU is a natural venue for students who have had an undergraduate research experience to present the results of their work and interact with other students as well as faculty and senior researchers. The CEU has been immensely successful in fostering this interaction, which helps students to have a broad introduction and exposure to research across nuclear physics, and to enable senior researchers to get to know some of the junior future leaders. Partial support will be provided for approximately 32 undergraduate students, out of a planned total of 150.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded approximately 32 undergraduate students to participate in the fall meeting of the Division of Nuclear Physics (DNP) as part of the 20th annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU) program in Pittsburgh, PA. During the meeting they met with professional physicists and one another, receive broad exposure to the quality and variety of cutting edge research conducted in the US and abroad, and observed how scientific results are disseminated at a professional meeting through formal presentations and informal conversation. In addition, for the 20th Anniversary of the CEU program, a special Plenary Session was organized featuring Nobel Laureate David Gross and CEU alumni.

There were 199 undergraduate student posters. Of these, 29% of the participants were women. Out of the self-identified students, 9% were Hispanic, 1% Pacific Islander, and 9% Black/African American (categories defined by the NSF).  Underrepresented minorities are especially encouraged to present their work at the conference which provides them with more advanced opportunities and helps propagate a more diverse workforce, which is a benefit to nuclear science, academia, and science as a whole.

This program has been successful in encouraging students to further their education in physics. The post conference survey (N=60) found a 10% increase of students interested in a PhD program in physics and 51% definitely or probably would attend for nuclear science.
